statement.tex:
%text Fuel expenditure for a steam-ship are proportional to the cube of its speed. It is known that a speed of 10 km/h, fuel costs are \$240/hour. Other expenses (independent of speed) amount to \$480 per hour \newline
At what speed should the ship travel to keep its \underline{total expenses per kilometre} lowest? And what will the total expense \underline{per hour} be at that speed? %

options.tex:
%text If $F$ be the fuel-costs per hour and $T$ the total costs per hour, then % \begin{align}
F \propto s^3 &\implies F = ks^3 \\ &\implies F = \dfrac{3}{17}\cdot s^3 \dph \\ \therefore T &= \left(\dfrac{3}{17}s^3 + 480\right) \dph \end{align} %text %

reason.tex:
%text We have been told that \[\qquad F \propto s^3 \implies F =k\cdot s^3 \] Moreover, % \begin{align}
F \left(10 \right) &= \underbrace{k\cdot \left(10 \kmph \right)^3 = 240 \dph}_{\text{Fuel costs at 10\kmph}} \\ \implies k &= \dfrac{240\dph}{(10 \kmph)^3} = \konst \frac{\$\cdot \text{h}^2}{\text{km}^3}\\ \therefore F &= \konst\dph \\ \text{and } T &= \left( F+480\right) \dph \\ &=\left(\dfrac{6}{25}s^3 + 480\right) \dph \end{align} %text %

options.tex:
%text If $T_k$ be the total cost \underline\text{per km}, then \[\quad T_k = \left(\dfrac{6}{25}s^2 + \dfrac{480}{s}\right)\dpk\]
\incorrect \[\quad T_k = \left(\dfrac{6}{25}s^4 + 480\cdot s\right)\dpk\] %

reason.tex:
%text In one hour, the ship would travel $s\text{ km}$ and incur a cost of $T$ dollars. Which means, that \underline\text{per km}, the ship spent % \begin{align}
T_k &= \frac{T}{s}\dpk = \frac{1}{s} \left[\konst + 480 \right]\dpk \\ &= \left[\frac{6s^2}{25} + \frac{480}{s} \right]\dpk \end{align} %text %
